prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

para.paratext: Three central legal principles govern the use of confidential business information in the context of the employment relationship.[1] First, employees are generally free to secure their livelihood without unnecessary restrictions on their ability to compete, even where they intend to leave their employment to enter into direct competition with their employer. Second, employers must be able to protect their legitimate business interests, including confidential information, corporate opportunities and customer connections. Third, certain employees, as a result of either the express terms of their employment contracts or the implied terms of their positions, owe their employers a higher duty both before and following their departure from employment.

Chapter 3 defined confidential business information. The purpose of this chapter is to outline the employment law doctrines that impact on the use of such information.[2] Generally, the courts have sought to harmonize the three legal principles just mentioned, with the ultimate aim of balancing the interests of the employer and the employee. The general legal assumption is that employees are free to compete with their employers, subject to six main categories of restraint:
the general good faith duty owed by all employees during their employment;
the employee's duty to provide reasonable notice of resignation from employment;
the duty of confidentiality (both at common law and as supplemented by contract);
express contractual terms contained in non-solicitation provisions (i.e., a “restrictive covenant”);
express contractual terms contained in non-competition provisions (i.e., a “restrictive covenant”); and
fiduciary obligations owed by higher level employees.

It should be noted that these duties will fall vicariously onto a new employer. Further, an absence of knowledge regarding any illegality will not normally assist the new employer in avoiding liability.[3]

The employment relationship is governed by general contract law principles. Put simply, an employee must perform in accordance with the contractual terms governing his or her employment. The terms of each employment contract may be specific and contained in formal documentation,[4] or they may be implied from the circumstances of the employment relationship, or both. In addition, all employment contracts assume certain “minimum” terms of employment as required by legislation, most notably statutes governing employment standards, human rights legislation and occupational health and safety. There are also duties that will be implied by the common law into every contract of employment.[5]
Some courts have argued that the same duties apply to independent contractors: Vancouver Telephone Co. v. Zanjani (1998), 78 A.C.W.S. (3d) 934 (B.C.S.C.).

For the most part, the basic nature of confidential business information is the same in the employment context as it is in other situations. In fact, the elements of confidential information have developed in conjunction with employment law principles, and the vast majority of the existing case law is employment-related. Accordingly, reference should also be made to Chapter 3 which outlines the essential elements of confidential business information.

See, for example, Edgar T. Alberts Ltd. v. Mountjoy (1977), 79 D.L.R. (3d) 108, 16 O.R. (2d) 682 (H.C.J.); 57134 Manitoba Ltd. v. Palmer (1985), 65 B.C.L.R. 355, 8 C.C.E.L. 282 (S.C.), supp. reasons 67 B.C.L.R. 100, 5 C.P.C. (2d) 155 (S.C.), affd 37 B.C.L.R. (2d) 50, 44 B.L.R. 94 (C.A.); and Clayburn Industries Ltd. v. Piper (1998), 62 B.C.L.R. (3d) 24, 44 C.C.E.L. (2d) 129 (S.C.).
E.g., employment contracts, letters to the employee from the employer, and company manuals or policy statements.
See for example CRC-Evans Canada Ltd. v. Pettifer (1997), 197 A.R. 24, 26 C.C.E.L. (2d) 294 (Q.B.), affd 216 A.R. 192, 175 W.A.C. 192 (C.A.).
